history.content: <md>Yes! I did this Fall 2020 and was perfectly fine, although it did help to read ahead a bit in the 149 book. Often, content was covered in 61C right before I needed to use it in 149, so things worked out. I actually thought this was a really nice pairing, as in 61c you code in C a fair bit in the beginning of the semester, and then forget about C for many weeks until the end of the semester. However, you will be using C all the time in 149, so that helped me from not forgetting how to use C for project 4 in 61C. Taking the classes together I think will strengthen your understanding of both material, and you will leave the semester very prepared to do cool stuff in embedded systems. Good luck!</md>

children.subject: <md>Sorry, I meant to respond to this earlier and completely forgot. Enrollment hasn't started yet so I guess we are good :) I would say the lecture/hw content is very theory sided, whereas the lab was pretty practical. There's _some_ overlap between the two, but not a whole lot. You can get a feel for lecture/hw content by looking at the (free) textbook [here](https://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/books/leeseshia/releases/LeeSeshia_DigitalV2_2.pdf), as lecture content and hw problems are straight from the textbook. You can get a feel for the lab content by taking a look at the lab textbook [here](http://bit.ly/3hnYwv3). Lab assignments mainly involved C programming reading micro controller documentation to get I/O to work on your robot and then also getting your robot to do basic tasks. The final project can be either theory/research or engineering-heavy/applied depending on what you choose to do.</md>
@Jay, would taking CS162 + EECS 149 be a good idea if I'm only taking 8 units? Also, what's the EECS 149 workload?
Whoops sorry I meant to respond to this earlier, let me know if you still have questions. I hope you got an answer '_'
Thanks for your reply! Would you say that EECS 149 is more theoretical /mathematical or more practical? What kinds of projects did you work on in the class?

If you are familiar with programming in C programming and are fine being confused a bit when memory concepts and state machines are brought up, I think you should be good to go. It would be super reasonable to self study these 3 things (C programming, memory concepts, state machines) over a break before taking the course. The staff when I took the course was also very supportive, so you can make sure to utilize them as a resource to help you understand the content. On the circuits side 16A should be enough and 16B focuses circuits in the first third anyway so you should be up to speed on that. I'm a little worried about your systems knowledge (controls/signal processing) lacking, and while that isn't required for the course, it helps contextualize some concepts/let you see why they are important and will enable you to do much cooler things in your final project. 149 is only offered fall by the way, if that affects your course planning.
How about 149 concurrently with 16B? I wasn't able to get in this semester and it's not offered this summer :(

I think 162 + 149 would probably be fine, there is a decent amount of overlap between the two classes and 149 is relatively low workload before the final project. I thought the problem sets weren't bad, although the lab was challenging for online. My group was still able to finish within the 3 allocated hours most of the time, but a few times needed to spend extra time. Would probably be easier working with people in person. The final project will probably be high workload for in person, but that is the last month-ish of the semester
would taking CS162 + EECS 149 be a good idea if I'm only taking 8 units? Also, what's the EECS 149 workload?

history.content: Can CS 61C be take concurrently with EECS 149?
